newsitem.title: USA: CBOT wheat closes higher on weather, exports.
newsitem.headline: CBOT wheat closes higher on weather, exports.

text.p: CBOT wheat futures closed higher on dry weather in portions of the Kansas wheat growing region and on spillover from Thursday's supportive USDA weekly export sales report, traders said.

"There are some signs of a little better demand. The export sales (Thursday's USDA weekly) were better than some people thought," said Jack Scoville, Vice President for Price Futures Group. "Also there are some forecasts for differing amounts of rain over the weekend."
Dry hard red winter wheat areas of western Kansas should be missed by next week's storm systems, meteorologists said.
Instead the storm system may bring rain to eastern Kansas, Oklahoma and Texas, they said.
The supportive demand picture surfaced this week with U.S. net export sales of old- and new-crop wheat combined during the week ended May 8 totaling 705,500 tonnes, according to the USDA.
That tally was above trade expectations for 350,000 to 500,000 tonnes.
Wheat closed four cents higher to three lower, with May up four at $3.87 and new crop July 1/4 cent higher at $3.88-3/4.
There also remained some concern about lingering dry weather in portions of Europe's wheat growing region.
"There's some world weather concerns about the wheat," said Charlie Sernatinger, analyst with E.D. and F. Man International. "We've got dryness in (Europe) and in western Kansas."

Technicians said the wheat market was oversold recently and was due for a correction. The nine day relative strength index (RSI) for the July reached a recent low of 31 percent at Wedneday's close and Friday closed at 34 percent. An RSI of 30 or less is indicative of an oversold market.
Refco Inc bought 2.5 million bushels of July, E.D. and F. Man International bought one million July and Rosenthal Collins bought one million bushels of July, traders said.
Wheat futures volume was estimated by the CBOT at 14,000 contracts, below the 17,147 traded Thursday.
In wheat options, Refco Inc sold 450 July $3.90 puts at 12-3/4 to 13 cents and bought 200 July $4.50 calls at two cents, traders said.
Wheat options volume was estimated at 5,000 contracts, below the 8,310 traded Thursday.
